Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Bruker EMXplus series EPR Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Patrick Farmer from Baylor University and colleagues Caleb Martin, Kevin Pinney, Bryan Shaw and John Wood will acquire an electron paramagentic resonance (EPR) spectrometer. This instrument will allow research in a variety of fields such as those that provide insight on how biologically relevant species behave when they possess unpaired electrons. In general, an EPR spectrometer yields detailed information on the geometric and electronic structure of molecular and solid state materials. It may also be used to obtain information about the lifetimes of free radicals, short-lived, highly reactive species involved in valuable chemical transformations as well as the initiation of pathological tumor growth. These studies will impact a number of areas, from the synthesis of inorganic and organic molecules to the development of new solid state materials to compounds of magnetic and biological interest. Employing examples inspired from ongoing research, this instrument will be an integral part of research and teaching at the undergraduate and graduate levels at Baylor University as well as Austin College, the University of Texas at Tyler and Texas Lutheran University.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) investigating biocoordination chemistry of HNO; (b) studying the mechanism of charge regulation in superoxide dismutase-1 and other metalloproteins; (c) studying the pro-oxidant chemistry of melanins; (d) designing, synthesizing and evaluating bioreductive tumor microenvironment; (e) analyzing radical reactions of trialkylborane water complexes; and (f) studying boron radicals, pyridyl phosphine/phosphine oxide coordination chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed the purchase a new EPR instrument for the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Facility of the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry at Baylor University.

Intellectual Merit. EPR spectrometers are used to identify the electronic structure of metal complexes and metalloproteins, the nature of transient intermediates in redox reactions, or the coupling of two radical sites over a distance.  The new EPR spectrometer has added capabilities for high resolution study of radicals from cryogenic temperatures to molecules in aqueous solution at room temperature. Specific research areas that have serviced by the EPR spectrometer are for studies involving metalloprotein and biological radicals, and small organic and inorganic molecules, from the groups (and funding agencies) of Profs. Broader Impact. This instrument has been used in the Advanced Instrumentation Workshop, an outreach program to provide students from smaller schools with exposure to instrumentation generally lacking at their home institutions.  The workshop consists of two days on campus during which a visiting student would attend several hands-on faculty-directed instrumentation workshops of 3 hrs each.  Faculty advisors are also invited to attend, and many do. Intramural support covers travel, meals, and overnight lodging costs for visiting undergraduates and for any faculty advisors attending. In the past 8 years, 243 students have attended along with 70 faculty, shown in Figure 1; in 2016 40 students and 12 faculty attended; In 2017, the11 AIW will be Nov 10-11, with xx students and yy faculty invited. Past participants represent 28 different institutions including four historically black colleges (Huston-Tillotson, Jarvis Christian, Paul Quinn and Prarie View A&M) as well as eight Hispanic-serving Institutions (Schreiner, St. Edward's, Sul Ross State, Texas A&M Kingsville, Texas Lutheran, UT at El Paso, U Houston and Incarnate Word). An estimated 30% of AIW students have been under-represented minorities, mostly Hispanic, and more than 50% women. The funded instrument is used for a workshop “Radicals characterized by EPR”. In the workshop, students are presented with EPR theory in pre-lab sessions, the students then synthesized three simple Cu(II) compounds and the EPR spectra of each obtained, Figure 2.
